title: [Icathia Lore] Nimcha Blades, for those curious
body:
As I've seen a few people discussing this, I figured I'd pop in, as a historical weapons enthusiast. The ***nimcha*** isn't actually something invented for Icathia, but an actual weapon used in Morocco and Algeria.

Something of a cross between a saber and a scimitar, they first appear in around the 18th century, and remain common into the 19th.

They range from the fairly straight to the very curved, as shown below, and I imagine our Icathian friends wield weapons more akin to the latter image than the former.

Speaking of things you might think are made up, but aren't: chitin is an actual biological compound found in the cell walls of fungi, the exoskeletons of arthropods (bugs, crustaceans, etc.), the radulae (basically the tongue) of mollusks, the beaks of cephalopods (octopus, squid, etc.), and the scales of fish and lissamphibians (frogs, newts, etc.). Of course, we see similar structures on the Voidborn, such as Kha'Zix's insect-like shell and the beak-like structure surrounding Vel'Koz's eye.

Also (and I learned this pretty late because I only ever read the word, instead of heard it) it's pronounced more like "kite-in" than with a "ch" sound.  That threw me for a while.

(And Papa Andrei - don't blame the n'wah.  It's not their fault.)

This ultimately comes from the fact that the word is Greek in origin.

The initial 'ch' is the romanized form of the Greek letter Chi (uppercase: Χ, lowercase: χ (though this font incorrectly displays it, it should be just as tall as the uppercase and descend below the baseline just like the roman letters g and p do), spelled χῖ in Greek).  Phonetically, it's essentially identical to the German pronunciation of 'ch', though depending on the accent the German form may be somewhat harsher by the standards of most English speakers.
